Thanks for all the helpful feedback folks :+1: ...I've added a new "Intermediate" tag (we only had beginner/advanced), and added Audience: developers creating forms programmatically at the top. It is now published: https://backdropcms.org/news/states-and-or-xor-conditionals-explained

@jenlampton @StPaulTim @Olaf Grabienski and others working on content/documentation for the main b.org site, do you think that we should add a new vocabulary, dedicated to target audience, and then allow tagging content of type blog, event, feature, and documentation with it? ...I was thinking that it could have terms like:

  • content editors
  • site builders (backenders)
  • themers (frontenders)
  • developers
  • site owners
  • project managers
@klonos - Great blog post. Could be published as is. I left one simple piece of feedback for you in private chat (to save space).

@klonos - Regarding your vocabulary idea, I don't have an immediate opinion, because I'm not sure how these tags are currently used or how useful they are or would be with this change.

I don't really work on "documentation" much on the main site, because I'm uncomfortable with the workflow. I don't know how to suggest changes for review and seldom am confident enough to just make changes. There are some exceptions to that and I have made some changes in areas where I am confident.

I hear you re documentation workflow @StPaulTim, but we need to work with what we have for now; so sometimes, just making changes may be necessary :shrug: ...I hope that perhaps at some point we will have a dedicated GitHub repo, where we can raise issues, and people can use revisions ...or we could use shared Google docs and the likes before the actual reviewed/approved documentation goes live.

...the intention of a dedicated "Target audience" vocabulary would be to avoid having to manually type that inside the content body (like I've done with this blog post). Our doco (Aussie shortened version of "documentation" :sweat_smile:) allows such dedicated entry of data, but uses a field instead: image.png

do you think that we should add a new vocabulary, dedicated to target audience ...?

Theoretically a good idea, but it would raise a lot of questions, e.g. naming of terms, or flexibility. Might make things more complicated.

but we need to work with what we have for now; so sometimes, just making changes may be necessary

Don't disagree. My point was, that I don't feel like I can say with any confidence that this will make things better or more useful. But, I am not against it either.

I'm open to a new vocab, but we don't have 'themers' or 'site builders' in
Backdrop.

We have backend developers (PHP/MySQL) frontend developers (HTML/CSS/JS)
and site architects (no end / all ends).

The intent with our terminology is to give everyone in our community a
little more respect than they got in the Drupal community.

Front end developers are developers too, let's not give them a title that
indicates that they aren't -- especially a title that isn't even a real
word (and since there is a difference between backed devs and frontend
devs, both types need the modifier).

I find it interesting that you instinctively group 'backend' with the site
architects, and not with the PHP/MySQL coders. Have you seen that
definition someplace else?
Agreed re "frontend devs" instead of "themers" @jenlampton ...in my list, I used the term "developers" to encompass both front/back-end devs.
Great post! I agree with @BWPanda - the screencast is very helpful to quickly get the idea. @klonos ++
klonos go team. (Karma: 13)

My point was, that I don't feel like I can say with any confidence that this will make things better or more useful. But, I am not against it either.

I feel the same, but only because we don't currently have any search tools. The only way people can get content on backdropcms.org is by how we feed it to them: the news/blog feed and it's taxonomy, the add-ons listings and their filters, and the site-architect documentation and its book navigation.

I'm not against adding another vocabulary and organizing content now, even if we don't add any tools for people to use it until later on. It will save us time when we do, we won't need to go back through and categorize everything then.
Excellent points!
